facts.text: The respondent was a firm carrying on a business of purchasing and selling paper, stationery and other things and manufacturing books, exercise books, diaries etc.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was a firm carrying on a business of purchasing and selling paper, stationery and other things and manufacturing books, exercise books, diaries etc. and for the purpose of its business it had a printing press.

facts.text: The firm had a printing press for the purpose of its business.

anchor.surface_text: and for the purpose of its business it had a printing press. The business was carried on and the press housed in a building belonging to its partners where the latter also resided.

facts.text: The business was carried on and the press housed in a building belonging to its partners where the latter also resided.

anchor.surface_text: The business was carried on and the press housed in a building belonging to its partners where the latter also resided. This building was requisitioned by the Government in September, 1943, for the duration of the war.

facts.text: The building was requisitioned by the Government in September 1943 for the duration of the war.

anchor.surface_text: This building was requisitioned by the Government in September, 1943, for the duration of the war. The respondent had thereupon to shift its business to another place where it was restarted sometime later.

facts.text: The respondent had to shift its business to another place where it was restarted sometime later.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had thereupon to shift its business to another place where it was restarted sometime later. The respondent claimed compensation for the requisition on various accounts and was paid various sums.

facts.text: The respondent claimed compensation for the requisition on various accounts and was paid various sums.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent claimed compensation for the requisition on various accounts and was paid various sums. One of the claims was made in these words On account of the compulsory vacation of the premises disturbance and loss of business on the basis of two years at Rs. 2,29,450 per annum Rs. 4,58,900.

facts.text: One claim was: On account of the compulsory vacation of the premises disturbance and loss of business on the basis of two years at Rs. 2,29,450 per annum Rs. 4,58,900.

anchor.surface_text: One of the claims was made in these words On account of the compulsory vacation of the premises disturbance and loss of business on the basis of two years at Rs. 2,29,450 per annum Rs. 4,58,900. On this head the Government paid Rs. 57,435.

facts.text: The Government paid Rs. 57,435 on this head.

anchor.surface_text: On this head the Government paid Rs. 57,435. The question is whether this sum of Rs. 57,435 was liable to income- tax and excess profits tax.

facts.text: The question is whether Rs. 57,435 was liable to income-tax and excess profits tax.

facts.text: The sum was paid in respect of some injury suffered by the respondent on account of the requisition.

issues.text: whether a certain sum received by the respondent was a capital receipt or a revenue receipt

anchor.surface_text: Sarkar, J. The question raised is whether a certain sum received by the respondent was a capital receipt or a revenue receipt. The respondent was a firm carrying on a business of purchasing and selling paper, stationery and other things and manufacturing books, exercise books, diaries etc.

issues.text: whether this sum of Rs. 57,435 was liable to income-tax and excess profits tax

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether this sum of Rs. 57,435 was liable to income- tax and excess profits tax. It would be liable if it was a revenue receipt and number, if it was a capital receipt. It was, numberdoubt, paid in respect of some injury suffered by the respondent on account of the requisition.

issues.text: whether there was injury to goodwill of the business as a result of shifting from old premises to new one due to requisition

anchor.surface_text: What is said is that there was a loss to the goodwill, that is to say, the benefit that the respondents business derived from its connection with the building where it was carried on. It is said that this benefit was lost as the business had to be shifted from the old premises to a new one as a result of the requisition. This is the contention that we have to examine in this case.

issues.text: whether the sum was received for injury to profit making apparatus apart from tangible capital assets

anchor.surface_text: What is said on behalf of the respondent is that there was injury to its profit making apparatus. Clark.

issues.text: whether the claim was for loss of goodwill or for loss of profits

issues.text: whether exempt from tax under section 4(3)(vii) of the Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: As it was a trading receipt, it cannot be held exempt from tax under section 4 3  vii  of the Income-tax Act either. In the result we answer both the questions framed in this case in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us for the reasons aforesaid that the sum of Rs. 57,435 had not been received by the respondent for any injury to any of its capital assets. In our view, the sum was received a compensation for loss of profits for the period during which, it was imagined, the respondents business would remain stopped before it could be re- started at a new premises.
In the result we answer both the questions framed in this case in the negative.
That being so, it was clearly a revenue receipt it has not been disputed that if the amount in question was paid as compensation for loss of profit, it would be a revenue receipt an liable to tax.
In the result we answer both the questions framed in this case in the negative.
